GS/LAW 60330.00Guided Study: LL.B. Number and Name of Course (Non-Credit)Where justified in the view of the supervisor and Director of the Graduate Program, candidates may be permitted to enrol in undergraduate LLB courses or seminars at Osgoode for audit purposes only. With permission of the course director the student attends the course as non-credit with no expectation of grade. They are not obliged to do coursework affiliated with the course.
GS/LAW 6033E0.00Guided StudyN/A
GS/LAW 6033B0.00Guided Study: LL.B. Number and Name of Course (Non-Credit)Where justified in the view of the supervisor and Director of the Graduate Program, candidates may be permitted to enrol in undergraduate LLB courses or seminars at Osgoode for audit purposes only. With permission of the course director the student attends the course as non-credit with no expectation of grade. They are not obliged to do coursework affiliated with the course.
GS/LAW 6033D0.00Guided StudyN/A
GS/LAW 6033A0.00Guided Study: LL.B. Number and Name of Course (Non-Credit)Where justified in the view of the supervisor and Director of the Graduate Program, candidates may be permitted to enrol in undergraduate LLB courses or seminars at Osgoode for audit purposes only. With permission of the course director the student attends the course as non-credit with no expectation of grade. They are not obliged to do coursework affiliated with the course.
GS/LAW 6033C0.00Guided StudyN/A
GS/LAW 6040A3.00Directed Reading
GS/LAW 60403.00Directed Reading
GS/LAW 6100P6.00Tax Policy, Statutory Interpretation and the Foundations of the Taxation of IndividualsTBA
GS/LAW 6101P1.00Advanced Legal Research WorkshopThis course provides opportunities for students in the PDP LLM to increase their skills in various aspects of legal research in preparation for major paper research.
GS/LAW 61236.00Economic Issues: Property, Pensions and Possession of the HomeThis course provides students with a solid grasp of the laws that apply to property issues in family cases.
GS/LAW 6127P6.00Non-Adversarial Resolution to Family Law DisputesThis course provides a theoretical framework and practice in development of skills related to the non-adversarial resolution of family law, including mediation, negotiation and collaborative family law.
GS/LAW 61303.00ICT ColloquiumFor graduate students who have the appropriate background expertise, this course provides the opportunity for extended discussions related to International. Comparative and Transnational Law. Prerequisites for Graduate Students: At least two LLB or graduate courses, or the equivalent.
GS/LAW 61313.00Study Group on Law in a Global Context IThis reading group will consider a broad swath of interdisciplinary and legal theoretical scholarship that seeks to address the question of the place of law in our current global order. Under the ambit of this topic would fall critical, feminist, postcolonial, and third world approaches to international law, law and development, legal and political theory, international economic law, as well as a range of interdisciplinary scholarship on globalization. Issues that may be taken up for discussion include the rule of law and the place of the exception, legal imperialism, the laws of war, global legal pluralism, transnational constitutionalism, the changing role of states and civil society in transnational governance, trade and development, and human rights. The reading group is envisioned as an engaged and collaborative undertaking. While the convener will propose a range of options for weekly topics and readings, participants will have the opportunity to participate in determining the specifics of the list over the course of the year.
GS/LAW 61320.00Study Group on Law in a Global Context IIThis reading group will consider a broad swath of interdisciplinary and legal theoretical scholarship that seeks to address the question of the place of law in our current global order. Under the ambit of this topic would fall critical, feminist, postcolonial, and third world approaches to international law, law and development, legal and political theory, international economic law, as well as a range of interdisciplinary scholarship on globalization. Issues that may be taken up for discussion include the rule of law and the place of the exception, legal imperialism, the laws of war, global legal pluralism, transnational constitutionalism, the changing role of states and civil society in transnational governance, trade and development, and human rights. The reading group is envisioned as an engaged and collaborative undertaking. While the convener will propose a range of options for weekly topics and readings, participants will have the opportunity to participate in determining the specifics of the list over the course of the year.

Under the ambit of this topic would fall critical, feminist, postcolonial, and third world approaches to international law, law and development, legal and political theory, international economic law, as well as a range of interdisciplinary scholarship on globalization. The reading group is envisioned as an engaged and collaborative undertaking. GS/LAW 61340.00Study Group on Law in a Global Context IVThis reading group will consider a broad swath of interdisciplinary and legal theoretical scholarship that seeks to address the question of the place of law in our current global order. Under the ambit of this topic would fall critical, feminist, postcolonial, and third world approaches to international law, law and development, legal and political theory, international economic law, as well as a range of interdisciplinary scholarship on globalization. Issues that may be taken up for discussion include the rule of law and the place of the exception, legal imperialism, the laws of war, global legal pluralism, transnational constitutionalism, the changing role of states and civil society in transnational governance, trade and development, and human rights. The reading group is envisioned as an engaged and collaborative undertaking. While the convener will propose a range of options for weekly topics and readings, participants will have the opportunity to participate in determining the specifics of the list over the course of the year.
GS/LAW 61353.00Study Group on Regulation & Governance IThe scholarship canvassed in this study group will address a broad set of questions concerning the role of regulation and governance in ordering social, economic and political life. One of the exciting things about the subject matter is that it is intensely debated by a broad range of scholars operating from a variety of perspectives, such as lawyers, sociologists, political scientists, economists, geographers, and legal and political philosophers. A range of fundamental questions may be recurring themes as we discuss our material. Such questions include; what exactly do we mean by regulation? Is it a coherent concept? Does it necessarily involve the state acting in some directive capacity? Is a regulatory agency required? What produces regulatory change? Do lawyers have a different understanding of regulation than non-lawyers? What are the indicia of good regulation? To what extent are regulatory norms or practices influenced by broader social, political or economic developments, such as globalization, neo-liberalism, or technological determinism? What are the tools of regulatory intervention? Is the distinction between social and economic regulation a viable one? How does the idea of governance differ from the idea of regulation? What are the new institutions of governance in the 21st century? Is there something unique about the phenomenon of risk regulation? What is the role of citizen engagement in regulatory activity?
GS/LAW 61360.00Study Group on Regulation and Governance IIThe scholarship canvassed in this study group will address a broad set of questions concerning the role of regulation and governance in ordering social, economic and political life. One of the exciting things about the subject matter is that it is intensely debated by a broad range of scholars operating from a variety of perspectives, such as lawyers, sociologists, political scientists, economists, geographers, and legal and political philosophers. A range of fundamental questions may be recurring themes as we discuss our material. Such questions include; what exactly do we mean by regulation? Is it a coherent concept? Does it necessarily involve the state acting in some directive capacity? Is a regulatory agency required? What produces regulatory change? Do lawyers have a different understanding of regulation than non-lawyers? What are the indicia of good regulation? To what extent are regulatory norms or practices influenced by broader social, political or economic developments, such as globalization, neo-liberalism, or technological determinism? What are the tools of regulatory intervention? Is the distinction between social and economic regulation a viable one? How does the idea of governance differ from the idea of regulation? What are the new institutions of governance in the 21st century? Is there something unique about the phenomenon of risk regulation? What is the role of citizen engagement in regulatory activity?

GS/LAW 61393.00Study Group Law & Economic Relations IThis Study Group will introduce participating students to fundamental concepts at the intersection of law and economic relations by exploring two greater strands, 1) Law Between State and Market, and 2) Contract and Governance. Drawing on Weberian sociology and the Political Economy scholarship in its aftermath throughout the 20th Century, the Study Group will explore the relationship between public and private ordering to unfold the relationship between the poles of Regulation Through Law and Regulation Through the Market.
GS/LAW 61400.00Study Group on Law and Economic Relations IIThis Study Group will introduce participating students to fundamental concepts at the intersection of law and economic relations by exploring two greater strands, 1) Law Between State and Market, and 2) Contract and Governance. Drawing on Weberian sociology and the Political Economy scholarship in its aftermath throughout the 20th Century, the Study Group will explore the relationship between public and private ordering to unfold the relationship between the poles of Regulation Through Law and Regulation Through the Market.
GS/LAW 61410.00Study Group on Law and Economic Relations IIIThis Study Group will introduce participating students to fundamental concepts at the intersection of law and economic relations by exploring two greater strands, 1) Law Between State and Market, and 2) Contract and Governance. Drawing on Weberian sociology and the Political Economy scholarship in its aftermath throughout the 20th Century, the Study Group will explore the relationship between public and private ordering to unfold the relationship between the poles of Regulation Through Law and Regulation Through the Market.
GS/LAW 61420.00Study Group on Law and Economic Relations IVThis Study Group will introduce participating students to fundamental concepts at the intersection of law and economic relations by exploring two greater strands, 1) Law Between State and Market, and 2) Contract and Governance. Drawing on Weberian sociology and the Political Economy scholarship in its aftermath throughout the 20th Century, the Study Group will explore the relationship between public and private ordering to unfold the relationship between the poles of Regulation Through Law and Regulation Through the Market.
GS/LAW 61433.00Advanced SecuritiesThis advanced seminar deals with the policy and practice of securities regulation in Ontario, in part by comparative analysis with other security regulation systems. The seminar will begin with a discussion of the philosophies of securities regulation and the role of the investor in changing markets. Specific seminar discussions will focus on issues currently being addressed and debated by securities regulators in Ontario and elsewhere, including: expansion of the civil liability regime public and private enforcement of securities law; the role of compliance approaches to securities regulation enforcement; the potential for national securities regulation n Canada; globalization of securities market, regulation of investment funds, legal issues related to on line investing; and the role of securities regulation in corporate governance in the post-Enron era. Prerequisite: Appropriate background experience (normally two courses at the LLB level)plus thesis/dissertation research in the area.
GS/LAW 61443.00Family Law PoliciesThis seminar focuses on family law policies and processes of family law reform. It explores critically underlying assumptions about families and family law in relation to the legislative and judicial development of family law policies and dispute resolution. The seminar assumes that students have a basic knowledge of family law in Ontario, and examines recent and proposed reform proposals in the context of fundamental theories and social policies. The seminar will focus initially on reading about theories and policies in family law, using one or more examples to explore the impact of the processes for family lawyers and their clients. Students will be expected to participate actively in these discussions, and to make brief presentation on assigned materials. In addition, students will choose a topic for a research essay that examiners the policy process in relation to a specific issue of family law reform, linking the course materials and discussions to their essay topics. Prerequisites: Advanced expertise (normally including completion of at least two LLB courses in family or related law) plus thesis/dissertation research in the area
GS/LAW 61453.00Intellectual Property TheoryThis seminar explores the theory surrounding the protection of creative intangibles under the legal category of intellectual property. The emphasis is upon exploring the fundamental theoretical premises, principles and policies that underpin IP systems. Over the last two decades, the power of IP rights-holders has expanded dramatically. It is important, therefore, to analyze the justifications for IP rights and their limits. The various theoretical foundation, and critiques of IP include theories based in: Lockean labour -desert, German idealist personality rights, economic utilitarianism, democratic governance, cultural studies, feminism, human rights and post-structuralism. The objectives of the seminar are: to develop students understanding of the theoretical framework for IP protection; to further students awareness of the practical and political significance of IP la; and to encourage students to critically evaluate the normatic bases of IP rights. Students will read and discuss a growing body of challenging academic scholarship about intellectual property theory. Prerequisites for graduate students: advanced expertise (normally including completion of at least two LLB courses in intellectual property, copyright, patents or trademarks) plus thesis/dissertation research in the area.
GS/LAW 61463.00Labour and Employment Law and Policy ColloquiumThis seminar examines contemporary issues in Canadian employment and labour law and policy and provides students with an opportunity to conduct supervised research on a topic of their choosing. Policy analysis and evaluation are emphasized, taking into account theoretical, historical and empirical perspectives. Theoretical perspectives includes neoclassical economics, institutional economics and Marxist political economy. Attention is paid to understanding labour market trends, including the growth of precarious employment, vertical and horizontal disintegration of production, increased labour force participation by women, and the problems experienced by young workers. The role of constitutional and international law may also be considered. Prerequisites for graduate students: appropriate background experience (normally two LLB courses in labour law or related field) plus thesis/dissertation research in the area
GS/LAW 61473.00Tax Law and Policy ColloquiumThe goal in this course is for students to bring together the knowledge and skills they have developed on tax issues, to develop their critical thinking and writing abilities, and to actively encourage the production of new knowledge in the tax field. Although the precise content of the seminar will vary from year to year, it will involve an examination of current research in tax law and policy. It will foster the high level of scholarly and professional sophistication needed to support thesis/dissertation research in the area. A the end of the seminar, students should have the ability to write publishable tax commentaries. Prerequisites for graduate students: advanced taxation expertise (normally including at least two LLB courses in tax) plus thesis/dissertation research in the area. Prerequisites: Graduate Students: Advanced taxation expertise (normally including completion of a t least two LLB courses in tax) plus thesis/dissertation research in the area.
GS/LAW 61493.00Introduction to Graduate Legal StudiesThis course is designed for students entering graduate legal studies without an LLB, JD or equivalent and will provide basic analytical frameworks and research skills necessary to approach legal issues.
GS/LAW 61490.00Introduction to Graduate Legal StudiesThis course is designed for students entering graduate legal studies without an LLB, JD or equivalent and will provide basic analytical frameworks and research skills necessary to approach legal issues.
GS/LAW 61513.00Study Group on Law and Social Justice IThe Study Group on justice will seek to tackle the elusive and sprawling question what is justice? The question has been posed since time immemorial and has elicited many and varied responses. The goal of the Study Group will not be to inculcate any particular approach or set of answers. Instead, it will canvass a range of topics and materials so as to enable students to receive a broad sense of the contemporary challenges to be met and pitfalls to be avoided in addressing this question. The readings will comprise an eclectic mix of inter-disciplinary material, drawing from political economy, philosophy, literature, economics, social theory, and, of course, law and jurisprudence.
GS/LAW 61520.00Study Group on Law and Social Justice IIThe Study Group on justice will seek to tackle the elusive and sprawling question what is justice? The question has been posed since time immemorial and has elicited many and varied responses. The goal of the Study Group will not be to inculcate any particular approach or set of answers. Instead, it will canvass a range of topics and materials so as to enable students to receive a broad sense of the contemporary challenges to be met and pitfalls to be avoided in addressing this question. The readings will comprise an eclectic mix of inter-disciplinary material, drawing from political economy, philosophy, literature, economics, social theory, and, of course, law and jurisprudence.

The goal of the Study Group will not be to inculcate any particular approach or set of answers. The readings will comprise an eclectic mix of inter-disciplinary material, drawing from political economy, philosophy, literature, economics, social theory, and, of course, law and jurisprudence.

The goal of the Study Group will not be to inculcate any particular approach or set of answers. The readings will comprise an eclectic mix of inter-disciplinary material, drawing from political economy, philosophy, literature, economics, social theory, and, of course, law and jurisprudence.
GS/LAW 61553.00Study Group on Theoretical Perspectives IThis group will investigate a motley crew of readings on legal pluralism, reflexive law, informal law, soft law and other perspectives which challenge the basic but largely unexplored assumption of most writing about law: that formal state law is the only significant form of law. Instead, for these purposes, state law will be treated as one amongst many competing normative systems, and not necessarily the most dominant. In addition to conventional legal-theoretical writing, group members may introduce work from the other social sciences, novels, serious journalism etc. Law will also be placed in its historical context, with resources drawn from legal history. Group members will be invited to speak to the readings from the perspective of whatever field of law is of particular interest to them - international, labour, criminal, corporate, family - and to reflect on the practical as well as the theoretical implications of these readings.
GS/LAW 61560.00Study Group on Theoretical Perspectives IIThis group will investigate a motley crew of readings on legal pluralism, reflexive law, informal law, soft law and other perspectives which challenge the basic but largely unexplored assumption of most writing about law: that formal state law is the only significant form of law. Instead, for these purposes, state law will be treated as one amongst many competing normative systems, and not necessarily the most dominant. In addition to conventional legal-theoretical writing, group members may introduce work from the other social sciences, novels, serious journalism etc. Law will also be placed in its historical context, with resources drawn from legal history. Group members will be invited to speak to the readings from the perspective of whatever field of law is of particular interest to them - international, labour, criminal, corporate, family - and to reflect on the practical as well as the theoretical implications of these reading.

Instead, for these purposes, state law will be treated as one amongst many competing normative systems, and not necessarily the most dominant.
